para.sentence: Another parametrization of (33.2.1) is given by \frac{{\mathrm{d}}^{2}w}{{\mathrm{d}r}^{2}}+\left(\epsilon+\frac{2}{r}-\frac{ \ell(\ell+1)}{r^{2}}\right)w=0, where r=-\eta\rho,\epsilon=1/\eta^{2}.
Again, there is a regular singularity at r=0 with indices \ell+1 and -\ell , and an irregular singularity of rank 1 at r=\infty.
When \epsilon>0 the outer turning point is given by r_{\mathrm{tp}}\left(\epsilon,\ell\right)=\left(\sqrt{1+\epsilon\ell(\ell+1)}- 1\right)\Bigm{/}\epsilon; compare (33.2.2).

The function f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is recessive (§2.7(iii)) at r=0 , and is defined by f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=\kappa^{\ell+1}M_{\kappa,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left( 2r/\kappa\right)/(2\ell+1)!, or equivalently f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=(2r)^{\ell+1}e^{-r/\kappa}M\left(\ell+1-\kappa,2 \ell+2,2r/\kappa\right)/{(2\ell+1)!} , where M_{\kappa,\mu}\left(z\right) and M\left(a,b,z\right) are defined in§§13.14(i)and 13.2(i), and \kappa=\begin{cases}(-\epsilon)^{-1/2},&\epsilon<0,r>0,\\ -(-\epsilon)^{-1/2},&\epsilon<0,r<0,\\ \pm\mathrm{i}\epsilon^{-1/2},&\epsilon>0.\end{cases } The choice of sign in the last line of (33.14.6) is immaterial: the same function f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is obtained. This is a consequence of Kummer’s transformation (§13.2(vii)).
f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is real and an analytic function of r in the interval -\infty<r<\infty , and it is also an analytic function of \epsilon when -\infty<\epsilon<\infty.
This includes \epsilon=0 , hence f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) can be expanded in a convergent power series in \epsilon in a neighborhood of \epsilon=0 (§33.20(ii)).

For nonzero values of \epsilon and r the function h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is defined by h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(\ell+1-\kappa\right)}{\pi \kappa^{\ell}}\left(W_{\kappa,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(2r/\kappa\right)+(-1)^{ \ell}S(\epsilon,r)\frac{\Gamma\left(\ell+1+\kappa\right)}{2(2\ell+1)!}M_{ \kappa,\ell+\frac{1}{2}}\left(2r/\kappa\right)\right), where \kappa is given by (33.14.6) and S(\epsilon,r)=\begin{cases}2\cos\left(\pi|\epsilon|^{-1/2}\right),&\epsilon<0, r>0,\\ 0,&\epsilon<0,r<0,\\ e^{\pi\epsilon^{-1/2}},&\epsilon>0,r>0,\\ e^{-\pi\epsilon^{-1/2}},&\epsilon>0,r<0.\end{cases } (Again, the choice of the ambiguous sign in the last line of (33.14.6) is immaterial.)
h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is real and an analytic function of each of r and \epsilon in the intervals -\infty<r<\infty and -\infty<\epsilon<\infty , except when r=0 or \epsilon=0.

The functions s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) and c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) are defined by s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=(B(\epsilon,\ell)/2)^{1/2}f\left(\epsilon,\ell;r \right),c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right)=(2B(\epsilon,\ell))^{-1/2}h\left(\epsilon,\ell;r \right), provided that \ell<(-\epsilon)^{-1/2} when \epsilon<0 , where B(\epsilon,\ell)=\begin{cases}A(\epsilon,\ell)\left(1-\exp\left(-2\pi/\epsilon ^{1/2}\right)\right)^{-1},&\epsilon>0,\\ A(\epsilon,\ell),&\epsilon\leq 0,\end{cases} and A(\epsilon,\ell)=\prod_{k=0}^{\ell}(1+\epsilon k^{2}).

An alternative formula for A(\epsilon,\ell) is A(\epsilon,\ell)=\frac{\Gamma\left(1+\ell+\kappa\right)}{\Gamma\left(\kappa- \ell\right)}\kappa^{-2\ell-1}, the choice of sign in the last line of (33.14.6) again being immaterial.
When \epsilon<0 and \ell>(-\epsilon)^{-1/2} the quantity A(\epsilon,\ell) may be negative, causing s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) and c\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) to become imaginary.

The function s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) has the following properties: \int_{0}^{\infty}s\left(\epsilon_{1},\ell;r\right)s\left(\epsilon_{2},\ell;r \right)\mathrm{d}r=\delta\left(\epsilon_{1}-\epsilon_{2}\right), where the right-hand side is the Dirac delta (§1.17).

When \epsilon=-1/n^{2} , n=\ell+1,\ell+2,\dots , s\left(\epsilon,\ell;r\right) is \exp\left(-r/n\right) times a polynomial in r , and \phi_{n,\ell}(r)=(-1)^{\ell+1+n}(2/n^{3})^{1/2}s\left(-1/n^{2},\ell;r\right) satisfies \int_{0}^{\infty}\phi_{n,\ell}^{2}(r)\mathrm{d}r=1.
